title: Pioneering RP-HPLC strategy for synchronous evaluation of assay and dissolution testing of piracetam and vincamine: A promising combination for cognitive and cerebrovascular disorders
authors: Samar M. Mahgoub; Lateefa A. Al‐Khateeb; Abdullah H. Alluhayb; Bandar R. Alsehli; Ammena Y. Binsaleh; Sayed M. Saleh; Mahmoud A. Mohamed
abstract: Abstract Cognitive and cerebrovascular disorders, such as dementia, Alzheimer's disease, and ischemic stroke, present significant global health challenges, particularly in aging populations. These conditions are characterized by cognitive decline and reduced cerebral blood flow, necessitating therapeutic strategies that address both aspects. Piracetam (PCM), a nootropic agent, enhances memory, learning, and neuroprotection. Vincamine (VCM), a cerebral vasodilator, improves blood flow and oxygen utilization. Their combination offers a synergistic approach to managing dementia impairment with vascular insufficiency. We evaluated RP-HPLC using AGREEprep and ComplexGAPI. PCM and VCM were measured concurrently in pharmaceutical formulations using RP-HPLC to ensure quality, safety, and efficacy. The process offered excellent linearity over a concentration range of 3–50 μg mL −1 for each drug, with coefficients of determination ( R 2 ) of 0.999. High sensitivity was achieved, with limits of detection (LOD) of 0.93 μg mL −1 for VCM and 0.32 μg mL −1 for PCM, and limits of quantitation (LOQ) of 2.81 μg mL −1 and 0.90 μg mL −1 . Accuracy studies revealed recoveries close to 100% for both drugs, with intra-day and inter-day precision showing RSD ≤2. System suitability parameters met pharmacopeial standards. Dissolution testing in media at pH 1.2, 4.5, and 6.8 revealed pH-dependent release of VCM, with 95.10% dissolution at pH 1.2 and 72% at pH 6.8 after 60 min. In contrast, PCM exhibited rapid and complete dissolution (>95% within 5 min) across all pH levels, consistent with its high solubility. These results validate the method as reliable for quality control and dissolution testing. This supports the development of this promising combination for cognitive and cerebrovascular disorders.

title: A fast, sensitive and greener stability-indicating HPLC method for the quantitative determination of osimertinib
authors: Samiah Alhabardi; Haya I. Aljohar; Amjad Majed Alganamy; Alanood S. Almurshedi
abstract: Abstract A rapid, sensitive, and environmentally friendly reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC) method was developed and validated for the quantitative determination of osimertinib, a third-generation EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor, in pharmaceutical formulations. The method utilizes an isocratic mobile phase of acetonitrile and 0.1 M ammonium acetate (1:1, v/v), with chromatographic separation achieved on a C18 column and detection at 276 nm. Method validation demonstrated excellent linearity over the range of 2.40–20.29 μg mL −1 ( R 2 = 0.9988), high accuracy (mean recoveries 90–105%), and precision (RSD <1% intra-day, <2% inter-day). Robustness testing confirmed the method's resilience to minor operational changes, and sensitivity was reflected in low limits of detection (0.843 μg mL −1 ) and quantification (2.55 μg mL −1 ). Forced degradation studies revealed significant osimertinib instability under acidic, alkaline, and oxidative conditions, but relative stability under thermal stress, confirming the method's stability-indicating capability. Greenness assessment using the AGREE tool yielded a score of 0.82, reflecting strong adherence to green analytical chemistry principles. This validated method is suitable for routine quality control and stability studies of osimertinib, offering both analytical reliability and environmental sustainability.

title: Development and validation of a new HPLC-UV method for the determination of gossypol in commercially available cotton oils
authors: Burhan Ceylan
abstract: Abstract Cottonseed is the second source of protein in the World after soybeans and the fifth in oil production. The most important use of cottonseed is in human and animal nutrition. Apart from this, the shell of cottonseed can be used in the cellulose industry and its inner part can be used as a medical drug due to its gossypol content. Gossypol is a phenolic compound that is a triterpenoid aldehyde or polyphenolic binaphtyl aldehyde. Gossypol has toxic and anti-fertility effects. For this reason, the gossypol substance contained in its seeds classifies its use in human and animal nutrition as a source of both protein and fat. The main goal of this work was to develop a high-performance liquid chromatographic (HPLC) method for measuring the amount of gossypol in different commercially available cotton oil samples that is rapid, straightforward, and accurate. Prior to chromatographic separation, liquid-liquid extraction was used for the preparation of samples, which is now the predominant extraction technique due to its simplicity, speed, and efficiency. Reversed phase C18 (5 µm × 4.6 mm × 150 mm) analytical column, methanol and water (0.1% o -phosphoric acid) (90:10 v/v) at a flow rate of 1.1 mL min −1 , and a UV detector that detected at 620 nm were used to achieve the chromatographic separation. The linear behaviour of the proposed approach was examined in the 0.01–30 μg mL −1 range ( r 2 = 0.9999). The proposed method is in alignment with the criteria that is established by International Conference on Hormonisation (ICH) about the accuracy, precision, repeatability, specificity, robustness and detection and quantification. Limit of detection and limit of quantification are determined to be 0.003 and 0.01 μg mL −1 whereas relative standard deviation was determined to be less than 1.03% for daily and hourly measurements. For stability tests, the highest RSD value among all conditions was found to be 3.44%. The method is an effective way of approach towards the detection of gossypol in different commercially available cotton oil samples. The suggested analytical process is a productive way to measure and regularly analyse gossypol in different commercially available cotton oil samples.

title: Persistence, dissipation and health risk assessment of spinosad and acephate in/on sapota fruits
authors: J.K. Gadhavana; K. D. Bisane; Susheel Singh; L. K. Saini; Vanrajsinh H. Solanki; T. R. Ahlawat
abstract: Abstract A research experiment was conducted at Fruit Research Station, Navsari Agricultural University, Gandevi, Gujarat to study the persistence, dissipation and health risk assessment of spinosad and acephate in sapota fruits. The first spray of insecticides was given at marble size fruit stage followed by 15 days of second spray. About 1.5 kg of sapota fruits were collected from each treatment at 0 (2 h), 1, 3, 5, 10, 20 and 30 days after last spray of insecticides. Analysis of the insecticide residues in sapota fruits was carried out by using the QuEChERS analytical method. On the basis of persistence and dissipation study, the half-life (DT 50 ) of spinosad and acephate in sapota fruits under recommended and double to recommended dose were varied from 1.11 to 1.32 and 2.52–3.73 days, respectively. The waiting period (WP) of spinosad and acephate in sapota fruits under recommended dose were 0.73 and 22.62 days, respectively. Further, Risk Assessment was evaluated and observed no risk for Indian consumer except 1–3 age group of children, due to studied insecticides under recommended doses (RQ < 1) in sapota fruits.

title: A new validated method for the determination of tofacitinib in human serum and pharmaceutical dosage form by HPLC-DAD
authors: Aysun Dinçel
abstract: Abstract The aim of this study was to develop a novel, rapid, simple, validated, and practically applicable HPLC-DAD method for tofacitinib analysis in human serum and pharmaceutical dosage. In serum test samples, tofacitinib and caffeine (internal standard, IS) were extracted using a simple liquid-liquid extraction process. Tofacitinib and caffeine were well resolved from the RP-HPLC system. The separation was achieved on XBridge, C18 (250 × 4.6 mm, 5 µm) analytical column with diode array detector (DAD) (285 nm) and isocratic elution. The mobile phase consists of a mixture of acetonitrile:NaH 2 PO 4 (20 mM) (35:65; v/v) (pH 4.2) at 1.1 mL min −1 flow rate. Tofacitinib and caffeine (IS) were eluted at 3.80 and 2.79 min, respectively, and the total run time was 5 min. Method validation was performed according to the ICH guidelines. The calibration curve was linear over a concentration range of 0.1–1.25 μg mL −1 ( r 2 > 0.995) mobile phase and serum. LOD and LOQ were found as 0.02 μg mL −1 and 0.06 μg mL −1 , respectively in human serum test samples. The recovery values for tablet formulation and spiked human serum for 1.0 μg mL −1 were found as 98.44% and 100.10% ( n = 6) respectively. A simple, sensitive, specific, and new high-performance liquid chromatographic (HPLC) method has been developed and validated for the determination of tofacitinib in human serum and tablet (Jandark) formulation. The validated HPLC method was successfully applied to the tofacitinib assay of human serum and tablet formulation.

title: Spectral characterization of Anchusa italica Retz. flowers and multidimensional analysis of rosmarinic acid in them based on high-performance liquid chromatography and high-performance thin-layer chromatography
authors: Linyang Wang; Chen Yan; Chen Pin; Shuge Tian
abstract: Abstract In this study, a multidimensional analysis of rosmarinic acid (RA) in the Anchusa italica Retz. flowers (Airfs) of was carried out by high-performance thin-layer chromatography (HPTLC) and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). The effective separation and detection of the analyte were achieved by optimizing the experimental conditions. These conditions included the thin-layer plate, the composition of the mobile phase, and the scanning wavelength. Concurrently, the HPLC fingerprints were established, and a similarity analysis of 10 batches of samples was conducted using a similarity evaluation system. This analysis revealed that the samples within each batch exhibited a high degree of similarity, suggesting that the compositions were characterized by a high degree of consistency. Furthermore, the spectral characteristics of Airfs were explored by analyzing them through three-dimensional fluorescence spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy. The present study employs a comprehensive analytical approach to elucidate the spectral characterization of RA in Airfs.

title: RP-HPLC method development, validation, and greenness profile evaluation: Concurrent quantification of telmisartan and atorvastatin calcium in combined pharmaceutical formulation
authors: Sarad Pawar Naik Bukke; Praveen Kumar Kusuma; Banothu Bhadru; Saraswathi Tenpattinam Shanmugam; Rajasekhar Komarla Kumarachari; Bayapa Reddy Narapureddy; Hope Onohuean
abstract: Abstract Objectives When formulating new strategies, contemporary analysts prioritize sustainability. Research in green analytical chemistry aims to replace hazardous reagents with eco-friendly alternatives and minimize waste generation. This study employed a comprehensive assessment of greenness evaluation tools. A newly validated RP-HPLC method was subsequently applied for the quantitative analysis of Telmisartan (TEL) and Atorvastatin calcium (ATV Ca) in both pure form and tablet formulation. Methods The analysis utilized an HPLC-UV Youngling Acme 9000 system with an Inertsil ODS RP column (250 × 4.6 mm, 5 μm), operating at 250 nm. The mobile phase, a 60:40 (v/v) blend of acetonitrile and phosphate buffer (pH 3.5), was delivered at 1.50 mL min −1 under isocratic conditions. Telmisartan (TEL) and Atorvastatin calcium (ATV Ca) showed retention times of 2.75 and 5.33 min, respectively. Results Calibration curves were developed to evaluate the linearity of TEL (10–100 μg mL −1 ) and ATV Ca (2.5–25 μg mL −1 ), showing a high R 2 of 0.999. The LOD and LOQ for TEL were 0.41 μg mL −1 and 0.23 μg mL −1 , while for ATV Ca, they were 1.246 μg mL −1 and 0.695 μg mL −1 , with recoveries averaging 98.59%–99.95% and 99.57%–99.98%, respectively. Validation of the method was performed following ICH guidelines. Moreover, the greenness assessment of the HPLC method was assessed using the AES, NEMI, AGP, AGREE, ComplexMoGAPI, AMGS, and BAGI. Conclusion This study validates the newly developed method and evaluates its environmental impact with multiple evaluation tools, confirming its eco-friendly nature, highlighting its potential as a responsible choice for analysing the mixture, especially in quality control labs and the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Development and validation of a robust RP-HPLC method for the quantitative analysis of roxadustat
authors: Faiza Faiza; Muhammad Saeed; Muhammad Zaman; Waqar Siddique; Ahmad Salawi; Yosif Almoshari; Jawaher Abdullah Alamoudi
abstract: Abstract Background Roxadustat is a HIF prolyl-hydroxylase inhibitor indicated for the treatment of chronic kidney disease (CKD) associated anemia. Approved in 2018, it has become a drug of great interest to researchers. In addition to its primary indication, roxadustat also exhibits cholesterol-lowering properties, even in patients who are not consuming lipid-lowering agents. The drug inhibits the HIF prolyl-hydroxylase enzyme, which increases iron uptake, reduces hepcidin levels, and promotes erythropoietin production. To facilitate reliable analysis of roxadustat, a validated high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) method was developed. This method ensures precision and reproducibility while offering improved temperature control, reducing potential fluctuations in results compared to previously reported methods. Results The HPLC method was developed on the Shimadzu HPLC system, equipped with a CTO-20AC oven and a DGU-20ASR photodiode array detector. The method employed a C-18 column (5 mm × 250 cm with a 0.5 µm particle size) and used a mobile phase consisting of ethanol and water (80:20 v/v). The flow rate was set at 0.8 mL min −1 , and the sample concentration was 150 μg mL −1 . The retention time for roxadustat was 6 min at a detection wavelength of 262 nm. Complete temperature control was ensured by maintaining the column temperature at 28 °C. Validation of the method was conducted by following ICH-Q2 guidelines. A series of tests, including linearity, precision, robustness, reproducibility, repeatability, specificity, and system suitability, were performed. For each test, the mean, standard deviation, percentage recovery, and percentage relative standard deviation (% RSD) were calculated. Additionally, the limit of detection (LOD) and limit of quantitation (LOQ) were evaluated during the validation process. Conclusion The developed HPLC method offers a reliable, precise, and reproducible approach for the qualitative analysis of roxadustat. The improved temperature control minimizes fluctuations in results, addressing limitations noted in previously reported methods. This method provides researchers with a robust tool for analyzing roxadustat with high accuracy and consistency.

title: Optimization and validation of RP-HPLC method for quantification of piperacillin in pharmaceutical formulation and in human blood plasma
authors: Tawseef Ahmad; Sirima Sitaruno; Zaheer Ullah Khan; Zubair Ahmed; Muhammad Atif; Sheikh Abdul Khaliq; Shujaat Ali Khan
abstract: Abstract A broad-spectrum antibiotic known as piperacillin is often used with tazobactam to treat infections caused by anaerobic bacteria as well as different Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. To ensure efficacy, it is important that piperacillin must reach therapeutic levels in the blood. An optimized, high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) serves as an ideal technique for accurate drug concentration analysis. In the current study, a validated reverse-phase HPLC method was developed for the determination of piperacillin in pharmaceutical formulation and human plasma. Acetonitrile was used to deproteinized the plasma samples, vortexed them, and reconstituted the supernatant with the mobile phase prior to HPLC injection. The analysis was performed by using a Waters Alliance HPLC system, which had a UV detector set at 218 nm and a flow rate of 1 mL min −1 . The mobile phase consisted of methanol, water, tetrabutylammonium chloride buffer, and phosphoric acid. The method showed linearity from 0.5 μg mL −1 to 400 μg mL −1 , with 99.9% recovery rate. The detection and quantification limits were 0.25 μg mL −1 and 0.5 μg mL −1 , respectively. The Cmax exhibits variability among patients, even when the same dose is administered to adult individuals. The method is both accurate and reliable, and the findings highlights the importance of individualized dosing based on variations in patients' plasma concentrations.

title: Pharmacokinetics and bioavailability of ricolinostat in mouse plasma by UPLC-MS/MS
authors: Lijing Zhang; Xicheng Dong; J. Chi; Yuqi Fan; Xiang Kai Xin; Fangmei Zhang; Xianqin Wang; Jianshe Ma; Lulu Zhang
abstract: Abstract Ricolinostat (ACY-1215), a selective Histone Deacetylase 6 (HDAC6) inhibitor, exhibits potent antitumor activity against a broad spectrum of tumors. UPLC-MS/MS technique was employed to identify ACY-1215 in mouse plasma and investigate its pharmacokinetic variations following oral (10 and 30 mg kg −1 ) and intravenous (5 mg kg −1 ) administration. Protein precipitation method utilizing acetonitrile as the solvent and cilostazol as the internal standard (IS) was used for plasma preparation. Chromatographic separation was achieved using an UPLC High Strength Silica (HSS) T3 column with gradient elution employing acetonitrile and 0.1% formic acid in water mobile phase. The linear range of the ACY-1215 standard curve spanned from 0.5 to 1,000 ng mL −1 , exhibiting excellent linearity. Intra-day and inter-day precision were both below 10%, while accuracy ranged from 90 to 108%. Matrix effect fell within the range of 104 to 108%, with recovery exceeding 92%. The bioavailability of ACY-1215 was determined to be 54.4 and 48.4% after oral administration at doses of 10 and 30 mg kg −1 , respectively. The pharmacokinetics of ACY-1215 were successfully evaluated using the UPLC-MS/MS method.

title: Integrated RP-HPLC approach for concurrent assay and dissolution analysis of artemether and lumefantrine: Leveraging MoGSA and RAPI
authors: Lateefa A. Al‐Khateeb; Abdullah H. Alluhayb; Sayed M. Saleh; Bandar R. Alsehli; Ammena Y. Binsaleh; Mahmoud A. Mohamed
abstract: Abstract Artemether (ART) and lumefantrine (LUM), two key components in antimalarial combination therapy, were assayed simultaneously and tested for dissolution using RP-HPLC. The purpose of this study is to present an eco-friendly RP-HPLC method that is combined with RAPI and MoGSA tools in order to assure an environmentally friendly analysis of both artemether and lumefantrine. In this method, acetonitrile, water, n-propanol, and trifluoroacetic acid were combined in a 50:40:10:1 ratio (v/v), at a flow rate of 1.3 mL min −1 , to achieve chromatographic separation. The ART and LUM detections were performed using UV detectors set at 210 and 236 nm, respectively, for the first 6.6 and 21.1 min, respectively. Both analytes were linearly detected over the concentration range of 3–60 μg mL −1 , with high recovery rates confirming their accuracy. ICH guidelines were followed to verify method reliability and reproducibility. Under specified dissolution conditions, at least 80% of the active substance of conventional immediate-release tablets was released within 45 min. Over a period of six months, accelerated stability tests confirmed the formulation's stability under stress conditions. Furthermore, MoGSA and RAPI scores classified the method as green and white respectively. In view of its robustness and durability, the method is suitable for routine quality control of ART and LUM in pharmaceutical formulations.

title: HPLC method development and validation for simultaneous analysis of methotrexate and leflunomide in bulk
authors: Nabeel Riaz; Umer Farooq; Zia ur Rehman; Hayaa M. Alhuthali; Hind A. Alzahrani; Muhammad Zaman; Waqar Siddique; Abida Khan
abstract: Abstract High performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is one of the commonly used techniques for the separation and quantification of various pharmaceuticals, both individually as well as in combination. The current studies were aimed to develop and validate a method for the simultaneous determination of methotrexate and leflunomide. These drugs are being used effectively for the treatment of rheumatoid and psoriatic arthritis. For simultaneous estimation of methotrexate and leflunomide, Shimadzu binary liquid gradient HPLC system, equipped with SPD-M40 photo diode array detector, DGU-20A 5R degassing unit, LC-20AD solvent delivery system, C18 column (4.6 mm × 250 mm, 5 µm) and, CTO-20AC oven, was used. Detection and quantification of both drugs were performed at 285 nm wavelength, using mobile phase, consisted of acetonitrile: water (65:35 v/v) along with 10% triethanolamine having adjusted pH 4.0 with ortho-phosphoric acid at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min −1 . The methotrexate and leflunomide were eluted at 1.99 and 6.45 min respectively, with sharp and distinguishing peaks. The Shimadzu's lab solution & Microsoft Excel 2016 was used for statistical analysis. The developed method was validated in accordance with USP <1225> and ICH guidelines Q2 (R1), for different parameters, including system suitability, specificity, linearity, range, accuracy, precision, LOD, LOQ, robustness and solution stability. The outcomes have confirmed that the method was validated with respect to studied parameters, as all of them were well within the specified limits.

title: Development and validation of a simple and rapid UPLC-MS/MS for determination of ginsenoside Rb1 in rat plasma and its pharmacokinetics
authors: Haichao Zhan; Xiaoyu Huang; Yingchang Zou; Congcong Wen; Xianqin Wang; Xueli Huang
abstract: Abstract Ginsenoside Rb1, as one of the main active ingredients of ginseng, has rich pharmacological effects and has been proven to have antioxidant, anti-apoptotic, and anti-inflammatory effects. In our work, a sensitive and selective UPLC-MS/MS method for determination of ginsenoside Rb1 in rat plasma was developed. Ziyuglycoside I was used as internal standard, protein precipitation by acetonitrile was used for plasma sample treatment. UPLC separation was achieved on a C18 with 0.1% formic acid and acetonitrile as the mobile phase with gradient elution. Multiple reactions monitoring mode was used for quantification, m/z 1154→1108 for ginsenoside Rb1, and m/z 811→603 for internal standard. Calibration plots were linear throughout the range 5–3,000 ng mL −1 . The recoveries ranged from 90.7% to 95.7%. RSD of intra-day and inter-day precision were less than 11.5%. The accuracy was between 91.4% and 111.5%. The method was successfully applied to pharmacokinetic study of ginsenoside Rb1 after intravenous and oral administration in rats. The bioavailability of ginsenoside Rb1 was found to be 0.41%.

title: Rapid and sensitive pyrotinib quantification in rat plasma via UHPLC-Q-Orbitrap MS for comprehensive pharmacokinetic studies
authors: Heyi Bao; Guofeng Li; Li Ding; Karl Wei; Hongyu Liu; Lixia Sun; Jing-qi Wang; Yong Sang Song; Shuxin Wei
abstract: Abstract Pyrotinib, a potent tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is pivotal in treating human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-positive breast cancer. This research established and validated an ultrasensitive and selective UHPLC-Q-Orbitrap MS method for plasma pyrotinib quantification. Utilizing an Acquity UPLC BEH C 18 column (100 × 2.1 mm, 1.7 μm), the method achieved efficient separation of pyrotinib and the internal standard imatinib through a gradient elution system with methanol (A) and water with 0.2% formic acid (B). Operating in positive ion mode, the Q-Orbitrap mass spectrometer employed full MS/dd-MS2 scans for comprehensive data acquisition, ensuring high analytical precision and accuracy. Pyrotinib was efficiently separated from plasma matrices within 5 min, demonstrating a robust linear range from 2 to 2,000 μg L −1 , with a low quantification limit of 2 μg L −1 . The method displayed excellent precision and accuracy below 5%, coupled with plasma extraction recoveries for pyrotinib consistently between 88.25% and 92.25%. This study presents a highly efficient analytical tool for pyrotinib quantification, which was successfully applied in the precise pharmacokinetic profiling of pyrotinib in rats after an oral dose of 5 mg kg −1 .

title: Minutes to measure: Ultra-fast and green HPLC-MS for flavonoid profiling in Citri Reticulatae Pericarpium
authors: Jiabi Liang; Qinggui Lei; Guodong Chen; Wenhao Wang; Weiqi Yang; Zhengming Qian
abstract: Abstract Citri Reticulatae Pericarpium (Chachi and Common mandarin), a dual-purpose traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) and food, contains bioactive flavonoids such as hesperidin, nobiletin, and tangeretin, which exhibit antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and cardioprotective properties. However, conventional high-performance liquid chromatography with ultraviolet detection methods for their quantification are time-consuming (>80 min), environmentally unsustainable (high organic solvent use), and lack sensitivity for low-abundance components (e.g., nobiletin, tangeretin). To overcome these limitations, this study developed a rapid, eco-friendly method by integrating vortex-assisted matrix solid-phase dispersion with Poroshell column and high-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (HPLC-MS), reducing analysis time to 4 min (1 min extraction + 3 min HPLC-MS) and cutting solvent consumption by 75%. The optimized protocol demonstrated highly sensitive and efficient enabling precise quantification of target flavonoids in 24 batches Citri Reticulatae Pericarpium (12 batches each of Chachi and Common mandarin). The contents of hesperidin, nobiletin, and tangeretin in 24 batches of samples were 28.18–78.56, 0.24–3.30, and 0.11–2.80 mg g −1 dry weight, respectively. Finally, the greenness of the developed method was evaluated using the green analytical procedure index, which indicated a superior environmental profile with five green regions. Additionally, the blue applicability grade index tool was employed, resulting in a score of 80, reflecting high applicability and environmental friendliness. Results validated the method's robustness for rapid quality assessment of Citri Reticulatae Pericarpium, supporting TCM standardization and clinical safety. This advancement aligns with green analytical chemistry principles and offers a transformative approach for ultra-fast, sustainable herbal analysis.

title: Study on Toddalia asiatica (L.) Lam. standard decoction based on HPLC characteristic chromatogram and content determination
authors: Yijie Zhang; Fangchan Li; Zijiu Liang; Xiuzhen Liang; Huijie Qin; Qing Chen; Huang Xiao-hong; Mengjiao Xie; Lin Jiang
abstract: Abstract Introduction The standard decoction of Toddalia asiatica (L.) Lam. (FLZX) possesses notable pharmacological properties including anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antimicrobial, and antiviral activities. However, its complex chemical composition necessitates the development of comprehensive quality assessment protocols to ensure consistent therapeutic efficacy. Objectives This study was designed to establish a reliable quality evaluation system for FLZX standard decoction through integrated analytical approaches, thereby facilitating quality control standardization. Methods Fifteen batches of FLZX standard decoctions were subjected to HPLC fingerprint analysis with similarity assessment. Multivariate chemometric analyses including cluster analysis (CA), principal component analysis (PCA), and orthogonal partial least squares discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA) were employed to evaluate origin-related variations. Characteristic peaks were identified and three major bioactive constituents were quantitatively determined. Results The established HPLC fingerprints contained eight characteristic peaks, with inter-batch similarities exceeding 0.900. Three bioactive markers (hesperidin, nitidine, and nitidine chloride) were unambiguously identified. Chemometric analysis revealed significant quality variations associated with geographical origin and harvesting period. Quantitative determination yielded concentration ranges of 0.850–3.829 mg g −1 for hesperidin, 3.612–10.251 mg g −1 for nitidine, and 0.087–0.335 mg g −1 for nitidine chloride, with corresponding transfer rates of 7.478–41.458%, 32.927–93.989%, and 3.235–17.392%, respectively. The extraction yields varied from 7.241% to 14.466%. Conclusion The combination of HPLC fingerprinting with chemometric pattern recognition establishes a robust quality assessment platform for FLZX standard decoction, providing both methodological and practical foundations for quality control in the production of related pharmaceutical preparations.

title: Gas chromatography–triple quadrupole (GC-Q3) applications for sampling and identifying chemicals emitted from musical instrument materials
authors: Minchao Wang; Zilong Tang; Zheyu Wang; Rui Wang
abstract: Abstract Synthetic components and coatings, adhesives, and plastics used in the construction of modern musical instruments also potentially emit hazardous substances. There is an increased understanding of the health effects of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and semi-volatile organic compounds (SVOCs), hence the need for better analytical tests for identification and measurement. This review critically discusses the advancements in detecting toxic compounds in musical instrument materials using gas chromatography coupled with triple quadrupole mass spectrometry, abbreviated GC-Q3. The aspects covered are the approach development, sample preparation processes, target compound groups, sensitivity levels, and concerns related to legislation and regulation. Using Headspace Solid-Phase Microextraction (HS-SPME) combined with GC-Q3 is one of the most effective, non-destructive, and sensitive methods. It also addresses possibilities for future work on standardization in the performing arts, green manufacturing, and directions for occupational and environmental safety in the performing arts.

title: Native gel electrophoresis on acrylamide basis for separating bovine serum proteins
authors: Babett Bartling; Patrick R. Winterhalter
abstract: Abstract Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) of native proteins is a diagnostic tool that helps to differentiate between acute and chronic inflammatory diseases in animals. SPEP is performed in horizontal zone electrophoresis systems with ultra-thin agarose gels or cellulose acetate membranes, or in the capillary zone electrophoresis without carrier material. Biomedical research laboratories more commonly use acrylamide gels as a carrier for protein analysis. As this is not applied for diagnostic SPEP, our study aimed to establish and characterize of an acrylamide-based SPEP with serum samples from cattle. This study showed the best electrophoretic separation of the serum protein fractions by use of concentration gradient gels (2−12% acrylamide/bis-acrylamide in Tris-acetate buffer) and Tris-taurine electrophoresis running buffer. Post-analysis of the protein bands by mass spectrometry identified those proteins contributing to the major SPEP fractions. While some proteins migrated in the expected fractions ( e.g., α1-antiproteinase, complement factor C3), others migrated elsewhere ( e.g., α2-macroglobulin, haptoglobin). In contrast to Tris-acetate/taurine buffer chemistry, Tris-borate proved to be the best buffer condition for separating the serotransferrin-containing fractions, allowing an appropriate differentiation of the individual transferrin serotypes. In summary, our study suggests electrophoresis protocols that can be used for bovine SPEP in acrylamide gels.

title: Simultaneous determination of acetyl salicylic acid (ACA) and salicylic acid (SA) in marketed enteric coated tablet dosage forms using UPLC method
authors: Wasim Ahmad; Nuzhat Banu; Ayaz Ahmad; Hasah Tariq Alshaheen; Danah Mshari Albalawi; Sedra Hani Almaskeen; Ahmed Adil Hilal; Nousheen Aslam; Rawan Rashad Al-Eid; Mohd Amir
abstract: Abstract Acetyl salicylic acid (ACA) is available as an over-the-counter medicine used as an analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic. In this article, a simple, sensitive, rapid, and precise ultra performance liquid chromatography (UPLC) analytical method was proposed for the simultaneous determination of Acetyl salicylic acid (ACA) and Salicylic acid (SA) in marketed enteric-coated tablet dosage forms. The current UPLC method was developed on Waters UPLC (Waters, Milford, USA), C8 column and column oven system controller was maintained at a temperature of 35 ± 5 °C. The mobile phase consists of the mixture of methanol: H 2 O: Orthophosphoric acid in water (OPA 0.1%) (60:30:10, v/v/v) for the simultaneous determination of ACA and SA in marketed enteric-coated tablet dosage forms. The maximum absorbance of ACA and SA was found to be 227.3 nm. The current UPLC method was validated as per the ICH guidelines. The developed UPLC method was found to be linear 62.5–312.5 and 56–280 ng mL −1 for ACA and SA, respectively. The LOD and LOQ were found to be 0.022 and 0.068 ng mL −1 for ACA, respectively, and 0.068 and 0.073 ng mL −1 , for SA respectively. The mean retention times of 1.012 ± 0.00 and 1.254 ± 0.00 were observed for ACA and SA, respectively. Moreover, the current UPLC method for the simultaneous determination of ACA and SA was rapid, accurate, precise, robust and highly sensitive. These observations demonstrated that ACA and SA in the marketed enteric-coated tablet dosage forms can be consistently analyzed by using the current UPLC method.

title: Development and validation of a rapid HPLC-UV method for simultaneous quantification of apomorphine and related impurities in drug products
authors: Abeer M. Al-Ghananeem; Sarah Baltzley; Abood A. Malkawi; Sai H. S. Boddu; Moawia M. Al-Tabakha; Sohaib Khan
abstract: Abstract Apomorphine, a potent dopamine agonist, plays a significant role in the management of advanced Parkinson's disease, and requires careful monitoring of the drug and its impurities for safety and efficacy. The USP monograph for Apomorphine Hydrochloride currently uses classical methods—titrimetry for assay and Thin-Layer Chromatography (TLC) for impurity testing—which, although effective, are not comparable in accuracy and speed to newer chromatographic techniques like High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC). For this, an HPLC method was developed using a C18 column, which possesses hydrophobic interaction capacity, and an isocratic elution mode with a mobile phase of 10 mM phosphate buffer (pH 3.0) and methanol (87.5:12.5) containing 0.075% L-tartaric acid. This combination allowed efficient separation of apomorphine from impurities without compromising stability. The method was thoroughly validated according to International Council for Harmonisation (ICH) guidelines and exhibited very good specificity, precision, accuracy, linearity, and robustness. The validation results demonstrated a good linear correlation ( r = 0.999) between the peak area and the apomorphine concentration, excellent precision (repeatability of 0.23% and intermediate precision of 0.56%), and accuracy (recoveries of 99.72–100.08%). Robustness was confirmed by minimal variation in percentage recovery ( R = 1.3%), and specificity was confirmed by the absence of interfering peaks caused by excipients or formulation components. The method has been successfully employed in the analysis of apomorphine and impurities in commercial products, proving itself reliable from batch to batch. This HPLC method represents a significant improvement over conventional methods, as it provides a precise and quicker approach for the quality control of apomorphine medicinal products.

title: FAST AND EFFICIENT PURIFICATION OF SYNTHETIC PEPTIDES BY SOLID-PHASE EXTRACTION
authors: Elżbieta Kamysz; Marcin Okrój; M. Łempicka; Tadeusz Ossowski; Jerzy Łukasiak
abstract: SUMMARY Post-synthesis purification of peptides is often the most difficult part of the synthetic procedure. In this study we describe the purification of two synthetic antimicrobial peptides (calcitermin and temporin A) by solid-phase extraction (SPE). Our results indicate that SPE is a rapid, inexpensive, and relatively efficient method for post-synthetic purification of synthetic peptides.

title: CHROMATOGRAPHIC QUANTIFICATION OF ISOFLAVONES (WHY AND HOW)
authors: Grzegorz Grynkiewicz; Hanna Ksycińska; Jan Ramza; Joanna Zagrodzka
abstract: SUMMARY Recent advances in chromatographic analysis of isoflavones, which can reach physiologically significant concentrations in human body fluids as a result of nutrition with food containing soy products or diet supplementation with phytoestrogen preparations, are surveyed and evaluated. Soy-derived food products and nutraceuticals are claimed to be beneficial for cardiovascular health and bone metabolism and to contribute signifycantly to cancer chemoprevention. Because clinical trials involving plantderived isoflavone-rich materials have been rather inconclusive, it seems important to discuss analytical means by which pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic data are generated. title: Determination of ciprofloxacin In human gingival crevicular fluid by high-performance liquid chromatography
authors: Aysun Dinçel; Ayhan Yıldırım; Feriha Çağlayan; Atilla Bozkurt
abstract: SUMMARY A simple and selective high-performance liquid chromatographic (HPLC) method has been developed for determination of ciprofloxacin in human gingival crevicular fluid (GCF). GCF samples were collected with paper strips. Ciprofloxacin was extracted from the pooled strips with methanol–water, 50:50 (v/v), and separated on a cartridge column (Radial-pak C18, 100 mm × 8 mm, 10 µm) with acetonitrile–sodium dihydrogen phosphate, 2:8 (v/v), as mobile phase at a flow rate of 2 mL min −1 . The effluent was monitored with a fluorescence detector at 280 nm (excitation) and 455 nm (emission). The retention times of ciprofloxacin and internal standard quinine sulphate were 4.55 and 13.25 min, respectively. The within-day and day-to-day precision were less than 9% for ciprofloxacin at 0.05, 0.1 and 0.4 µg mL −1 (n = 6), the within-day and day-to-day accuracy values were in the range 96.33–102.67% for ciprofloxacin at the concentrations given above and the detection limit corresponding to a signal-to-noise ratio of 3:1 was 3 ng mL −1 .
